questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents with esotropia, which increases on focusing near objects. This issue has progressively worsened over the past few months, and she has difficulty with close visual tasks. A refractive error of +6.50 D has been identified. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Accommodative Refractive Esotropia

(Option A)

Accommodative Non-refractive Esotropia

(Option B)

Accommodative Mixed Esotropia

(Option C)

Cause

High hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D)

Abnormal large AC/A (accommodative convergence/accommodation) ratio

Combination of hypermetropia and high AC/ A ratio

Treatment

Correction of hypermetropia (spectacles)


 
  • Corrected by bifocal glasses with +3 DS added for near vision
  • Miotics (Echothiophate)
  • Surgery: Bilateral medial rectus recession

Surgery: Bilateral medial rectus recession

questions.text: A 7-year old child is brought to the clinic by her parents due to concerns about her right eyes appearing misaligned. On examination, her squint remains constant in all directions of gaze. She does not report any diplopia, and there are no limitations in eye movement. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65 year old woman presented to the OPD with her head tilted towards the right side. On examination, she was having left hypertropia which increases on looking right or medially. The muscle which is most likely paralyzed is:

A 40-year-old patient presents for binocular vision assessment. The ophthalmologist performs the Worth’s Four Dot Test. The patient wears red-green glasses and reports seeing three green dots. What does this finding most likely indicate?

During a Maddox rod test, the patient is asked to view a distant light source. With the Maddox rod placed in front of the right eye, the patient reports seeing a vertical red line to the right of the white light. What type of ocular misalignment does this result suggest?
questions.explanation:
Measure the Horizontal Deviation with Maddox rod test

 
  • The red lines of the Maddox rod are placed horizontally in front of the right eye so that a vertical line is formed.
  • The patient is then asked whether the white light is superimposed on the horizontal red line or not.
  • Patient might see the light source right or left to the red line.
  • If superimposed - normal.
  • If the patient is seeing the red line to the left of point light: Exotropia or crossed diplopia (as image moves inwards, eye moves outwards). (Option B)
  • If the patient is seeing the red line to the right of point light: Esotropia or uncrossed diplopia. (Option A)

Measure the Vertical Deviation with Maddox rod test

 
  • The red lines of the Maddox rod are placed vertically in front of the right eye so that a horizontal line is formed.
  • The patient is then asked whether the white light is superimposed on the horizontal red line or not.
  • Patient might see the point light source up or down to the horizontal line.
  • If superimposed - normal/orthophoria.
  • If the point light source is above the red line: right hyperphoria or left hypophoria. (Option C)
  • If the point light source is below the red line: right hypophoria or left hyperphoria. (Option D)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with eyelid retraction on downgaze. He has a history of ocular nerve injury. Which of the following best describes this condition?

A 7-year-old girl has limited abduction of the left eye, with globe retraction and narrowing of the palpebral fissure on adduction and widening of the fissure on attempted abduction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Duane Retraction Syndrome Type I
questions.explanation:
Feature

Type I

Type II

Type III

Abduction

Limited

Normal

Limited

Adduction

Normal or mildly limited

Limited

Limited

Globe Retraction

Present on adduction

Variable

Present on adduction

Palpebral Fissure on Adduction

Narrows

Slight change

Narrows

Palpebral Fissure on Abduction

Widens

No significant change

Slight change

Pathophysiology

Absent CN VI; CN III innervates LR

CN III innervates LR

Co-contraction of LR and MR

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with the following symptoms: right-sided facial weakness, right-sided lateral gaze impairment, and weakness on the left side of the body. Imaging reveals a ventral pontine lesion. Which of the following syndromes best describes this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Syndromes

Cause

Features

Foville Syndrome

(Option D)

Damage to the dorsal pontine area affects the abducens nucleus, facial nucleus, and descending corticospinal fibres.
  • Sixth Nerve Palsy
  • Seventh Nerve Palsy
  • Contralateral Hemiparesis
  • Central Horner Syndrome

Millard-Gubler Syndrome

(Option B)

Ventral pontine injury affects the abducens nerve fascicle and facial nerve fibres.
  • Lateral Rectus Weakness
  • Ipsilateral facial paralysis
  • Contralateral Hemiparesis

Moebius Syndrome

(Option C)

Congenital condition affecting cranial nerve development.
  • Facial Nerve Palsy
  • Eye Movement Abnormalities: The eyes may exhibit esotropia (inward turning) or exotropia (outward turning).
  • Orofacial Dysmorphism: Abnormalities in facial structure, which may include difficulty with suckling and phonation in infants.

Gradenigo Syndrome

(Option A)

Mastoiditis leads to infection and inflammation near the petrous apex of the temporal bone.
  • Abducens Nerve Palsy: Difficulty moving the eye laterally, often associated with pain.
  • Facial Pain: Pain may be present due to involvement of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Deafness: Associated with mastoiditis, which results in pain and deafness.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has double vision and an inward deviation of his left eye. On examination it is found to be associated with 6th Cranial Nerve Palsy. What finding is typical for sixth cranial nerve palsy?

options.label: C
options.text: Head turn towards the same side, avoiding diplopia

questions.correct_answer: C. Head turn towards the same side, avoiding diplopia

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient reports diplopia and is found to have left trochlear nerve palsy. Which of the following findings is not typically associated with it?

options.label: B
options.text: No diplopia with head tilt away from the left side

options.label: D
options.text: Increase in hypertropia on opposite gaze

questions.correct_answer: A. Diplopia relieves while going downstairs

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with the following findings. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Syndrome

Cause

Features

Weber's Syndrome

Injury to cerebral peduncle.

Third nerve palsy on the same side (ipsilateral) as the affected eye, combined with contralateral hemiplegia (paralysis on the opposite side of the body).

Benedict's Syndrome

Injury to the Red nucleus

Third nerve palsy with contralateral hemi-tremors, chorea & athetosis.

Nothnagel's Syndrome

Injury to the Superior Cerebellar Peduncle

Third nerve palsy with ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia (balance and coordination problems on the same side as the affected eye).

Claude's Syndrome

Lesion in the midbrain affects both the oculomotor nerve (CN III) and the red nucleus.

Third nerve palsy, ipsilateral cerebellar ataxia, and contralateral hemi-tremors.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with sudden onset double vision and difficulty aligning his eyes, which began three weeks ago. He has a history of hypertension and recently experienced a mild stroke. Examination reveals that his eye is positioned downward and outward. Which of the following statements about this condition is incorrect?
How much is the difference in deviation between upward gaze and downward gaze in A-V pattern strabismus?
questions.explanation:
Amount of deviation

‘A’ pattern

‘V’ pattern

Between upward and downward gaze

≥ 10 PD or prism dioptre

≥ 15 PD or prism dioptre

Esotropia (in upward gaze)

Increases

Decreases

Esotropia (in downward gaze)

Decreases

Increases

Exotropia (in upward gaze)

Decreases

Increases

Exotropia (in downward gaze)

Increases

Decreases

questions.text: A 45-year-old male complains of double vision, describing seeing two overlapping images when looking in a specific direction. He reports that this problem started suddenly about two weeks ago and is most noticeable when looking towards the right side. There is no history of trauma. On examination, he has limited movement of the right eye towards the right. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Uniocular diplopia

Binocular diplopia
  • Subluxation of lens (Option C)
  • Polycoria (multiple pupils)
  • Incipient cataract
  • Keratoconus
  • Paralysis of extraocular muscles (e.g. paralytic strabismus) (Option D)
  • Orbital lesions
  • Orbital fractures (e.g. blowout fracture) (Option A)
  • Thick pterygium (Option B)
  • Symblepharon
  • Thyroid ophthalmopathy
  • Decentred spectacles
  • Anisometropia

questions.text: Which of the following is known for its specific pattern of muscle insertions around the sclera, essential for the alignment and movement of the extraocular muscles?
questions.explanation:
Medial Rectus

Inserts closest to the limbus, about 5.5 mm from the limbus.

Inferior Rectus

Inserts 6.5 mm from the limbus.

Lateral Rectus

Inserts 6.9 mm from the limbus

Superior Rectus

Inserts the farthest, about 7.7 mm from the limbus.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is having trouble catching a ball, climbing stairs, and performing fine motor tasks. She has a tendency to avoid activities requiring precise hand skills. No developmental delay was detected. Which of the following tests would be appropriate for diagnosing her condition?

The parents of an 8-month-old girl have observed her eyes misaligning, especially when she focuses on objects up close, with one eye occasionally turning inward. They consulted an ophthalmologist, who conducted the test shown below. What is the name of this test?

A 10-year-old boy's parents noticed his left eye turning inward, especially when tired or focusing on near objects. An ophthalmologist diagnosed strabismus and performed the test shown below. Which statements about this test are correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It indicates the angle of squint

options.label: B
options.text: In an aligned eye, the reflex is centred

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with eye strain and headaches. The ophthalmologist plans to perform a series of tests to evaluate the patient’s strabismus. All of the following are objective tests used to assess strabismus except?
questions.explanation:
Objective Tests

Subjective Tests
  • Corneal Light Reflex Test (Hirschberg Test, Krimsky Test)
  • Bruckner Test
  • Cover-Uncover Test
  • Prism Bar Test
  • Synoptophore
  • Maddox Rod Test
  • Maddox Wing Test
  • Lancaster Red-Green Test
  • Hess Screen
  • Haploscopic Devices (Major Amblyoscope)

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with increased diplopia on upward gaze and restricted movement of the left eye. The patient also has a history of recent orbital trauma. To determine whether the limitation is due to a mechanical restriction or a nerve palsy, which of the following tests is most appropriate?

A 10-year-old patient presents to the clinic with complaints of occasional double vision and eye strain during schoolwork. On examination, you suspect she may have a squint and perform the following test. What is this test known as?
Which of the following options correctly identifies the type of strabismus depicted in each image? 1. 2. 3.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Incomitant Strabismus

Concomitant Strabismus

Magnitude of Squint

Varies with eye position

Same in all positions

Diplopia

Present

Absent

False Projection

Present

Absent

Abnormal Head Posture

Present

Absent

Secondary Deviation

Secondary > Primary

Secondary = Primary

Ocular Movements

Restricted

Full

questions.text: Which mechanism is responsible for maintaining coordinated movement of both eyes and achieving binocular vision?
questions.explanation:
Conjugate & Dysconjugate Movements

 

(Option A)
  • Synkinesis refers to the simultaneous movement of both eyes in the same direction, essential for maintaining binocular alignment.
    • This is known as conjugate movement.
  • Dysconjugate movements occur when the eyes move in opposite directions, such as during convergence (both eyes move inward) or divergence (both eyes move outward).

Synergistic & Antagonistic Muscles

 

(Option B)
  • Synergistic muscles contract together to move both eyes in a specific direction.
    • Eg: In Dextroversion (rightward gaze), the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus act as synergists.
  • Antagonistic muscles are those that relax or are inhibited during these movements.
    • Eg: In Dextroversion, the right medial rectus and left lateral rectus are antagonists.

Yoke Muscles

 

(Option C)

Yoke muscles are pairs of synergistic muscles in each eye that work together to achieve coordinated eye movements.

  • Eg: In the Rightward gaze, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus are yoke muscles that contract together to move the eyes in the same direction.

Neurological Control
  • Hering's Law of Equal Innervation ensures that both eyes receive equal and simultaneous neural input to the synergistic (yoke) muscles during conjugate movements.
  • Sherrington's Law of Reciprocal Innervation states that increased activation of a muscle is accompanied by decreased activation of its direct antagonist muscle.

Ocular Motor Nuclei and Pathways
  • The control of eye movements involves several brainstem nuclei, including the oculomotor (III), trochlear (IV), and abducens (VI) nuclei.
  • These nuclei coordinate eye movements through neural pathways, such as the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which connects various eye movement centres.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with diplopia and difficulty looking upwards and to the right, with limited elevation of the right eye. You suspect a lesion affecting a muscle responsible for vertical movement. Which axis describes the rotational movement, and which muscle is likely affected?
questions.correct_answer: D. Fick's x-axis; Right Superior Rectus
questions.explanation:
Axis

Direction

Movements

Muscles Involved

X-Axis (Horizontal)

Runs horizontally from the outer corner to the inner corner.

Elevation (upward) and Depression (downward)

Superior Rectus, Inferior Rectus

Y-Axis (Anteroposterior)

Runs anteroposteriorly from the front (cornea) to the back.

Intorsion (inward rotation) and Extorsion (outward rotation)

Superior Oblique, Inferior Oblique

Z-Axis (Vertical)

Runs vertically from the top of the head to the chin.

Adduction (inward) and Abduction (outward)

Medial Rectus, Lateral Rectus

questions.text: Which physiological principle explains that during eye movement, an increase in neural stimulation to a contracting muscle is accompanied by a proportional decrease in stimulation to its opposing muscle?

A 25-year-old patient presents with a condition in which, upon examination, the left eye fails to adduct during right gaze. The patient reports diplopia, which is more noticeable when looking to the right. Which extraocular muscle is most likely overacting in this patient's condition?

A 45-year-old patient presents with vertical diplopia that worsens when looking down, especially while walking downstairs. Examination reveals weakness in intorsion, depression, and abduction of the affected eye. Which muscle and cranial nerve are most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Extraocular muscles and actions

Muscle

Primary Action

Secondary Actions

Innervation

Medial Rectus

Adduction (moves eye inward)

None

Oculomotor nerve (CN III)

Lateral Rectus

Abduction (moves eye outward)

None

Abducens nerve (CN VI)

Superior Rectus

Elevation (moves eye upward)

Intorsion (inward rotation), Adduction

Oculomotor nerve (CN III)

Inferior Rectus

Depression (moves eye downward)

Extorsion (outward rotation), Adduction

Oculomotor nerve (CN III)

Superior Oblique

Intorsion (inward rotation)

Depression, Abduction

Trochlear nerve (CN IV)

Inferior Oblique
